GAME THREAD: Louisville vs Kentucky Football

Rpayne LouisvillePosts: 82Member ✭✭✭✭✭
November 23 edited 8:13AM in University of Louisville
Lets get this discussion on the right thread......LOL

There are a lot of possibilities hanging in the balance for both teams.
UK can become bowl eligible, which wasn't expected back in September
UL needs a big W just in case Ga Tech falls to Georgia and Fla State.... and Clemson loses to South Carolina. The Cards could land an Orange Bowl bid Correct me if I am wrong in this scenario for the Cards

I have to believe that Stoops has taken this time off to re-energize his team just one last time. He can become Brooks-like if he can get that infamous 6-6 Bowl eligible record on the books, when the best everyone predicted for this team was 3-4 wins.

Petrino has to make sure everyone gets their head out of the clouds and feet firmly planted on the ground before Saturday at Noon. Senior Day / Rival Game / Possible Orange Bowl Bid should help keep the Cards focused on the task at hand.

My Uk friends tell me this team is just beat up and tired, and are expecting a bad loss.
I buy some of that.
I believe that UK is better than their record and last 2 performances show.

I also believe that the Cards have yet to put a complete game together. What better day to do that than on Saturday?

Cards 45 Cats 31
Post edited by JonathanLintner at 8:13AM

  • dshwildcats Central KentuckyPosts: 207Member ✭✭✭✭✭
    November 23
    Rpayne,

    "My Uk friends tell me this team is just beat up and tired, and are expecting a bad loss."

    Your Kentucky friends have hit the nail on the head, brother! As I said after the Georgia and UT games, this is a football team that is just physically and mentally spent! I'm sure the bye week this weekend had to help them; but, I'm not sure it's enough to help them pull off the upset against the Cards.

    I believe if these two teams had played in late September/early October, the Cats could've defeated the Cardinals. That is definitely not the case now. Louisville's offense is much more prolific with Parker and Dyer in the lineup. Their defense, while not as stout as they were in the early and middle part of the season, is still good enough to keep Kentucky's offense in check (much like Mizzou and UT did).

    To be honest, Kentucky would've stood a better chance if Gardner hadn't gone down. Kentucky has always had problems with a mobile QB! I believe Kentucky's DEs, Smith and Dupree, will get into the Louisville backfield. But, Bonnafon has the ability to avoid the rush, and turn a potential loss into a big play. Add that to the fact that Kentucky's tackling has been abysmal lately, and you have a recipe for disaster.

    I'm not quite ready to make a prediction yet. I'm waiting to see if there's a change in the forecast for Saturday. I'm still holding out for a cold, snowy morning/afternoon on Saturday! 25 degrees and snow would mean less than a full house at the "Pizza Palace", which would give Kentucky a better shot at pulling the upset. I'm also hoping that Petrino spends the week referring to Kentucky as the "slapd**ks" to his players! Lol!! If Louisville is still patting themselves on the back for the ND win, and they are taking Kentucky lightly, the Cats at least have a "puncher's chance"!

  • Rpayne LouisvillePosts: 82Member ✭✭✭✭✭
    November 24
    Not sure why Card fans act so surprised that no one except for them holds Bobby in such high esteem. Kentucky fans weren't the only ones who believed that UofL sold its soul to the devil by hiring this guy back. I read a lot of national articles after he was hired back, and everyone pretty much had the same reaction: "What the h*ll are they thinking??" Thank goodness Mitch had a little integrity and never considered this guy. This is one season ticket holder he would've lost if he had

    This Card fan doesn't hold Petrino in high esteem. Never has and never will. He might be our football coach, but I have never affiliated myself to a coach, especially in football. I support my Cards, no matter who is on the sideline running the show.
    He did things to people that I know very well..... Greg Nord as an example. Greg has told me stories that make your skin crawl. And the way he left UL, and the way he treated those asst coaches. I Grew up with the Nords....Greg is a class act even though he played and coached for UK.
    So I understand the "hate" that other fans have for our head coach.
    In the same breath, I also believe in 2nd chances, and people given an opportunity to right a wrong. I don't condone a lot of his past actions, yet I will support our program and Tom Jurich.
    And I wont give up my season ticket because I love my Cards....not because I support Bobby Petrino. There is a difference. The players deserve my support. Petrino wont be here forever.... but UL will.

    Ok off that soapbox......My hope is that the Cards put together "that" game that we have all been waiting for. 4 quarters that the fans and the Seniors will remember for a long time. 4 quarters up and down the field, never ending. 4 quarters that makes the opposition say ok....Uncle I give.
    4 quarters that if the planets align themselves, gives us a chance to go to the Orange Bowl because we beat Uk by 30-40 points and make the pollsters take notice.
    No more 21 point leads that evaporate in the 4th quarter. Give me a 21 point lead that grows, doesn't shrink. Give me a game that Petrino HAS to have his QB Take a hmmmm knee in the closing seconds on the 5 yard line.

  • dshwildcats Central KentuckyPosts: 207Member ✭✭✭✭✭
    November 25
    Rpayne,

    Good post, brother!! Like you, I support the kids and school, not the coach. I don't get caught up in all of the "Calipari" love like a lot of Kentucky fans. I like Coach Cal; but there have been coaches before him at Kentucky, and there'll be coaches after he leaves.

    I also believe in giving people 2nd chances. But, when it comes to 4th, 5th, 6th....chances, I'm not quite as willing. Western showed that someone out there was going to give this guy another shot. And a bigger school would have eventually hired him away from Bowling Green if Louisville hadn't. I just thought it looked bad on the part of Jurich and the University to bring him back.

    All that being said, I still can't envision myself sitting in the stands and watching a coach like Petrino leading a group of young men on the field, especially a group of young men wearing the Blue and White. Thank goodness I didn't have to make that choice.

    I love your take on the game, brother! Lol!! With the way Kentucky's defense has played in the last two games, they could quite possibly give you that 30-40 point victory you crave. Although, I'm not sure how much the pollsters would sit up and take notice! Lol!! I believe Louisville is the better team, but I think that the Kentucky that showed up in Gainesville, beat the Ol' Ball Coach, and played very competitive against Miss. State could give Louisville all they wanted. Problem is, we haven't seen that Kentucky for a while now. On offense, Kentucky's OL has looked really bad against Mizzou, UGA and UT. Mauldin should have a field day beating Kentucky's OTs off the edge. Kentucky's young playmakers have suddenly disappeared. And Towles hasn't looked so poised in the pocket the past few games.

    On defense, the DL very rarely reestablishes the LOS. More often than not, they're being driven backwards 5 or 6 yards. Our LBs are often out of position, which allows what should be a 2 or 3 yard run to turn into a 20 yard run. And, I'm not sure that our DBs could cover me right now. The tackling, or lack thereof, reminds me of watching my middle school team! The past couple of games has been like watching Hal Mumme's defenses!!

    OK! Off of my soapbox! Lol!! My only hope is that these kids will come out Saturday morning, see that "Louisville" across the front of the jersey, get fired up, and want to him someone in the mouth (figuratively, not literally). Louisville is a good team, but they are not "Georgia or Mississippi State" good. There's no reason for Kentucky to fear this team.

    As for Petrino taking a knee, if he's in the situation to do so, he might want to do it! Lol!! As I said in another post, Stoops doesn't seem like the kind of coach that takes too kindly to the score being intentionally run up on his team. This Louisville team loses a lot this year; while Kentucky will have the majority of its major contributors coming back. And, Louisville comes to our place next year.

    It is rivalry week and anything can happen. One year Florida came into the game 5-0 and FSU was 0-5. FSU killed them. Stats and records go out the window in these games. More upsets on these Saturdays than any other. Cards have to be prepared for the shock factor in the first quarter. You know Stoops is coming up with something new to get the edge early. Weather may be a factor..........just have to wait and see on that until Friday.

  • dshwildcats Central KentuckyPosts: 207Member ✭✭✭✭✭
    November 26
    wildcard said:

    It is rivalry week and anything can happen. One year Florida came into the game 5-0 and FSU was 0-5. FSU killed them. Stats and records go out the window in these games. More upsets on these Saturdays than any other. Cards have to be prepared for the shock factor in the first quarter. You know Stoops is coming up with something new to get the edge early. Weather may be a factor..........just have to wait and see on that until Friday.

    wildcard,

    Good point about the way things sometimes play out in rivalry games. If Kentucky were to upset Louisville on Saturday, I have watched college football long enough to say that I've seen stranger things happen.

    On offense, Kentucky had better dip into its bag of tricks. They've had plenty of time to prepare some things that Louisville hasn't seen on film. The "wildcat" formation would be a good change of pace, if the "wildcat" player (Jojo Kemp) didn't run the ball every single time!! There are several options out of the "wildcat" formations; but, Neal Brown has chosen not to explore any of those options this year (i.e. like simply handing the ball off to the motion man!).

    On defense, Kentucky will have to bring down one of their Safeties and load the box in an attempt to slow down Louisville's rushing attack. Problem is, that leaves a DB on an island with Parker, which is a total mismatch. Definitely a "Catch 22" situation!

    Speaking of the Noles and Gators, I would love to the Gators knock off Jimbo, Jameis and the "renegades" from Tallahassee! I am by no means a Florida fan; and, I'm not particularly fond of Muschamp. But, it is the SEC vs. ACC. Plus, Jimbo seems to be running the kind of program that Florida ran under Urban Meyer; or, that Miami had in the 80s under Johnson and Erickson.

    I would like to see the SEC grab at least two of the four rivalry games with the ACC this weekend. Of course, for that to happen, there'll need to be at least one upset along the way. I think the best chance for an upset is South Carolina at Clemson.

    Rpayne,

    I do look for Kentucky to play better on Saturday. But, I'm not sure that's going to be enough, brother. I think Parker and Louisville's stable of RBs give them a big advantage over Kentucky. In Kentucky's last 4 games, they have given up 250 yards rushing per game. That stat alone doesn't bode well for the Cats. I look for Louisville to pound it on the ground; pound it some more; and then go play action to Parker!

    I think Kentucky's only chance of pulling the upset is to create some TOs; and, get some big plays on special teams (an area that has absolutely killed them in several games). They are not going to win this game simply going toe-to-toe with Louisville. At this point, Louisville is just more talented, and more physical than Kentucky.

    TonyMontana said:

Seems that Winston is the grabbing all the negative press unlike the other regimes whom had multiple run-ins with law enforcement.     Sorry brother, but there's a lot more going on down there than just Winston's shenanigans! The problems have been well publicized.

    Just a couple of examples:

    "TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — In the early morning hours of Oct. 5, as this college town was celebrating another big football victory by Florida State University, a starting cornerback on the team drove his car into the path of an oncoming vehicle driven by a teenager returning home from a job at the Olive Garden. Both cars were totaled. But rather than remain at the scene as the law requires, the football player, P. J. Williams, left his wrecked vehicle in the street and fled into the darkness along with his two passengers, including Ronald Darby, the team’s other starting cornerback.
    The Tallahassee police responded to the off-campus accident, eventually reaching out to the Florida State University police and the university’s athletic department. By the next day, it was as if the hit and run had never happened."

    "A Tallahassee man who was robbed during a drug deal gone bad in June said the transaction was set up by Florida State University running back Karlos Williams, according to a Tallahassee Police Department incident report. In addition to Winston and Williams, starting wide receiver Jesus "Bobo" Wilson was arrested this year for stealing a scooter and several players face criminal mischief charges for firing BB guns. Earlier this year, Prince represented former wide receiver Greg Dent who was charged with sexual battery, but pleaded to a lesser charge. In January, another FSU football player was involved in a domestic dispute."

    "Florida State running back Karlos Williams is under investigation over an accusation of domestic battery, the Tallahassee Police Department announced Monday."

    Sorry, brother!! Smells like a thug, looks like a thug--probably a thug!! But, good ol' Jimbo blames all of the media attention on his renegade program on ESPN and SEC! Classic!! There ya go, Jimbo! Way to teach your players to be accountable for their own actions! Lol!!

    "Dadgummit, fellas! These are just good ol' boys having a little fun!"

    And, you know I've got to fire back with something about all of UofL's issues! Lol!!

    Here's a little excerpt from one of Eric Crawford's articles about the mess Steve Kragthorpe inherited when Petrino left the first time. In the piece, Jurich defends Kragthorpe because of all the players he had to send packing after Petrino bolted for the Falcons. Funny how TJ never brought up any of these issues when he had to find a proven coach to replace Charlie Strong. Oops!! I keep forgetting--Bobby Petrino is a changed man! Lol!!

    "If you're a booster, or heard Jurich speak in the years after Petrino left on numerous occasions, you heard him speak of problems in the program that had to be cleaned up. The number of players Steve Kragthorpe wound up dismissing for substance abuse issues, for one, was a problem. They wouldn't discuss it at the time. Couldn't discuss it, "for legal reasons," Kragthorpe said. The same way Rick Pitino couldn't be specific when dealing with the dismissal of Chane Behanan. But they weren't problems that Kragthorpe created. They were problems he inherited. (I outlined the good and the bad in this partial accounting of the difficulty of life post-Petrino in this column.)

    Of Petrino's 2006 recruiting class, his last at U of L, only three players were starting just three years later and only seven were playing regularly. In a December, 2008, interview, Jurich told me: "Bobby went to areas where he thought he was strong recruiting and some of them panned out and some didn't. That's the nature of it. But listen, we had to clear out a lot of discipline issues. And our numbers suffered. We cleared 21 kids out of here, and that's a lot. That's a big hit for anybody to take, Eric. I don't know anyone that has. But we want to do things the right way.""
